Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the step-parent needs to respond
Situation2: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Story: I stared at my phone, the school’s number still glowing on the screen. My stepson, Ethan, had been caught bullying a classmate. The principal wanted me to come in immediately to discuss what happened. My heart pounded with worry and guilt—Ethan needed me to show up, to prove I cared, to help him through this. But just as I was grabbing my keys, my work phone buzzed. The main production unit was down again, sensor errors halting everything. My supervisor’s message was blunt: “We need you on the floor now. Every minute counts.” I could almost hear the hum of the machines, the pressure of the team waiting for my diagnosis. I felt torn in two—Ethan’s anxious face on one side, the urgent demands of the factory on the other. Both needed me, both expected me to fix things, to be present, to make it right. My hands shook as I stood in the hallway, keys in one hand, work badge in the other, paralyzed by the impossible choice.
